title: 103_hr4962
content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited as the short title. It amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. Membership includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Steering committees will be appointed, and ex officio members will include a US House Representative. The Management Conference for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes a citizens' advisory committee and ex officio members, such as the US House Representative. Within a year, a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan must be published, outlining duties and timelines for federal and state agencies. The pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin must suggest a timetable for adoption by federal and state agencies, describe funding methods, incorporate environmental management concepts, and include a strategy for water pollution prevention. The Administrator, in cooperation with the Management Conference, will provide for public review and comment. The Administrator, in cooperation with the Management Conference, will provide for public review and comment on the draft Plan. The Plan will be approved if it meets the requirements and will be implemented upon approval. Grant assistance will be available. Upon approval of the comprehensive conservation and management plan, grants may be provided by the Administrator to assist in its development, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs. Non-Federal sources must provide the remaining share, which can include in-kind services. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for grants to develop the Coeur d'Alene Basin watershed in northern Idaho. The section does not affect the jurisdiction of any US or State department or agency related to the Basin. Appropriations are authorized to the EPA for this purpose. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for grants to develop the Coeur d'Alene Basin watershed in northern Idaho, including entities related to the Basin created by treaty. Appropriations are authorized to the EPA for fiscal years 1995-1999. Federal program coordination is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by developing an integrated geographic information system, converting recording sites to monitoring stations, and establishing additional monitoring sites for basic data collection and groundwater mapping. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish additional monitoring stations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin for data collection, groundwater mapping, and fisheries resources restoration. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will establish monitoring stations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin for data collection, groundwater mapping, and fisheries resources restoration. Additionally, there will be a dedication of hatchery production within the basin and a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey conducted, including surveys of threatened and endangered species, migratory bird populations, and other species of concern. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving the health of fishery resources, conducting investigations on fishery resources status, and updating a survey of fishery resources and habitats in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999 to support these activities. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with other trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes creating a geographical information system inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas, and cleaning up these sites. The restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleaning up mining contaminated sites, developing stream and river restoration plans, monitoring restored areas, and implementing a land management plan to reduce human health and environmental risks. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes developing a land management plan to reduce health and environmental risks, creating a geographical information system for cultural and ecological resources, and implementing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans. Monitoring of wildlife management areas for effectiveness is also included in the plan. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes developing a land management plan to reduce health and environmental risks, creating a geographical information system for cultural and ecological resources, implementing wildlife and fishery habitat management plans, monitoring wildlife management areas, developing an integrated public recreation management plan, and implementing a lake and river information program. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, contaminated lands, and resource information management. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory, restoration, and management of mining waste source areas and contaminated lands, as well as design, construction, and maintenance of restoration projects and management facilities. They are also responsible for overseeing the construction of repositories for mine waste, managing public use information, recreation supervision, long-term restoration and land management plans, and providing maintenance for restored public lands. Authorization of Appropriations: The Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management, is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 1995-2002 to carry out activities related to restoration, management of contaminated lands, and maintenance of restored public lands. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of the Interior are exempt from liability under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 for actions taken under this Act.
